title: Diff'rent Strokes star Danny Cooksey's wife of over 20 years files for divorce
text:
He was a child actor who gained public recognition for his role the 1980s hit sitcom Diff'rent Strokes and again in 1991 in the wildly successful sci-fi film Terminator 2.

But now, some three decades on, actor Danny Cooksey is heading to divorce court.

His wife Amber Leigh Cookey filed a legal divorce petition, citing irreconcilable differences, according to TMZ.

Splitsville: Different Strokes child star Danny Cookey's wife, Amber Leigh Cooksey, has filed for divorce after 21 years of marriage

Cooksey, who played Sam McKinney during the final three seasons of the hit sitcom, and his estranged wife have been married for more than 21 years.

They have two children together: daughter Zoe, 21, and son Jackson, eight.

Amber is asking for sole legal and physical custody of Jackson, that includes visitation rights for Danny.

She's also asking the court to award her spousal support, block Danny's attempt at getting spousal support from her, and change back to her maiden name of Leigh.

Big breakthrough: Cookey played little Sam McKinney alongside star Gary Coleman, during the last three seasons of Different Strokes from 1984-1986

Danny Cooksey, now 43, appeared in 48 episodes of Different Strokes from 1984 through 1986.

He quickly transitioned with a role on the sitcom The Cavanaughs from 1986 to 1989.

His other TV credit include: Tiny Toon Adventures (1990-1992), Salute Your shorts (1991-1992), 101 Dalmatians: The Series (1997-1998), Dave The Barbarian (2004) and Kick Buttowski: Suburban Daredevil (2010-2012).

Family matters: Cooksey, 43, shares daughter Zoe (center), 21, and son Jackson (left), eight, with his estranged wife

Most recently he has voiced the role of Snag in the 2019 pilot episode of the animated series Long Gone Gulch.

As a 14-year-old in Terminator 2, he played Tim, the red head with the mullet hairdo that befriends Edward Fulong's character John Connor.

He also voiced the roles of Brett and Chet in the 2012 animated comedy film The Lorax, which also starred the voices of Danny DeVito, Ed Helms, Zac Efron and Taylor Swift.
